ground_truth: He is chairing the Congress, and Jinnah bows, takes his notes, and gestures to the auditorium—a man made for and loving the spotlight. At last, he moves back to his place on the platform, where Nehru clasps his hand in congratulation, and others crowd around him. Fleetingly, on the edge of the picture, we see Gandhi, the only one in an Indian tunic, sitting at the end of the second row on the platform, just watching the flood of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone, stilling the house with upraised hands, and the audience cheers and applauds his little coda. He raises his hands again, stilling them, as Gandhi has already started to come toward the podium. Gandhi is greeted with mild applause because the convention is performing like one now that the spell of Jinnah's major speech has dissipated. As Gandhi reaches the podium, Patel gestures him to it, and Gandhi nods to him, acknowledging the residue of applause. Patel wanders back toward the others, his mind already on them, but he half-hears Gandhi's comment and turns with a smile, demonstrating a politician's flexibility. Gandhi grins and takes glasses from his sleeve—this is the first time we have seen them. He has one slip of paper with notes which he puts on the podium. He puts his glasses on and faces the convention, while on the platform, whispered politics continue, and on the convention floor, some listen as others talk of different things. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's last remark, turns, and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the hall too. Jinnah listens aloofly and challengingly, then takes off his glasses, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman flashes a picture, prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. On the platform, leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one peasant face, Shukla, who we will come to know, watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru, who has been observing Gandhi with interest and some surprise, turns to Patel. An open touring car struggles along a bumpy trail with Nehru driving, accompanied by four friends as young as he, all dressed in the same expensive, British manner. Nehru looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is half-finished, with unworked ground and partially completed buildings, looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: He is presiding over the Assembly, and Jinnah inclines, takes his notes, and gestures to the auditorium—a man crafted for and adoring the limelight. Eventually, he shifts back to his spot on the platform, where Nehru clasps his hand in commendation, and others throng around him. Briefly, on the boundary of the picture, we observe Gandhi, the sole one in an Indian tunic, seated at the finish of the second row on the platform, merely watching the tide of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone, quieting the house with uplifted hands, and the audience cheers and applauds his brief coda. He elevates his hands again, silencing them, as Gandhi has already commenced coming toward the podium. Gandhi is greeted with mild applause because the convention is performing like one now that the spell of Jinnah's significant speech has dissipated. As Gandhi reaches the podium, Patel gestures him to it, and Gandhi nods to him, acknowledging the remnant of applause. Patel meanders back toward the others, his mind already on them, but he half-hears Gandhi's remark and turns with a grin, showcasing a politician's adaptability. Gandhi beams and takes spectacles from his sleeve—this is the first time we have seen them. He has one slip of paper with notes which he places on the podium. He puts his spectacles on and faces the convention, while on the platform, murmured politics continue, and on the convention floor, some listen as others talk of various things. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's final remark, turns, and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the hall too. Jinnah listens distantly and defiantly, then removes his spectacles, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman flashes a photograph, prompting lukewarm applause taken up here and there. On the platform, leaders join in mechanically as we see one peasant face, Shukla, who we will come to know, observing from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru, who has been studying Gandhi with interest and some surprise, turns to Patel. An open touring vehicle struggles along a bumpy trail with Nehru driving, accompanied by four companions as young as he, all dressed in the same costly, British style. Nehru looks a little harassed from the teasing and the rough ride. The ashram is half-completed, with untended ground and partially completed structures, looking like a primitive frontier settlement. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The Congress is being chaired by him, and notes are taken by Jinnah, who bows and gestures to the auditorium—a man made for and loving the spotlight. At last, his place on the platform is moved back to by him, where Nehru clasps his hand in congratulation, and others crowd around him. Fleetingly, on the edge of the picture, Gandhi, the only one in an Indian tunic, is seen by us, sitting at the end of the second row on the platform, just watching the flood of enthusiasm for Jinnah. The microphone is approached by Patel, who stills the house with upraised hands, and his little coda is cheered and applauded by the audience. His hands are raised again by him, stilling them, as Gandhi has already started coming toward the podium. Mild applause greets Gandhi because the convention is performing like one now that Jinnah's major speech has dissipated its spell. As Gandhi reaches the podium, he is gestured to it by Patel, and Gandhi nods to him, acknowledging the residue of applause. Patel wanders back toward the others, his mind already on them, but Gandhi's comment is half-heard by him, and with a smile, he turns, demonstrating a politician's flexibility. Gandhi grins and takes glasses from his sleeve—this is the first time they have been seen by us. One slip of paper with notes is put on the podium by him. His glasses are put on by him, and he faces the convention, while on the platform, whispered politics continue, and on the convention floor, some listen as others talk of different things. Gandhi's last remark is caught by Nehru, who turns, and now the floor of the hall also begins to focus attention. Jinnah listens aloofly and challengingly, then takes off his glasses, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman flashes a picture, prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. Leaders on the platform join in perfunctorily as one peasant face, Shukla, who we will come to know, is seen watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Gandhi is observed with interest and some surprise by Nehru, who then turns to Patel. A bumpy trail is struggled along by an open touring car with Nehru driving, accompanied by four friends as young as he, all dressed in the same expensive, British manner. From the ragging and the rough ride, Nehru looks a little harassed. The ashram, half-finished with unworked ground and partially completed buildings, looks like a primitive frontier outpost. Finally, they are brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He chairs the Congress, with Jinnah bowing, gesturing, and enjoying the spotlight before returning to the platform, where Nehru congratulates him, and others gather. Gandhi, in an Indian tunic, sits watching the enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel quiets the audience with raised hands and receives applause. He signals Gandhi to the podium, who receives mild applause as Jinnah's speech effects fade. Patel returns to the group, half-hearing Gandhi's comment and smiling. Gandhi grins, retrieves glasses from his sleeve, and places a note on the podium. On the floor, some listen as others chat. Nehru catches Gandhi's last remark, shifting focus to the hall floor. Jinnah listens aloofly, removes his glasses, and returns to the platform as a cameraman snaps a photo, sparking lukewarm applause. Leaders join perfunctorily as Shukla, a peasant face in the doorway, watches. Nehru observes Gandhi with interest, turning to Patel. An open car, driven by Nehru with four young friends dressed in British style, struggles along a bumpy trail. Nehru appears harried by the rough ride. The half-finished ashram resembles a primitive frontier outpost, and they finally stop due to a goat tethered across the path.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Chairing the Congress, Jinnah bows, gestures to the auditorium, and returns to the platform, where Nehru congratulates him. Gandhi, in an Indian tunic, sits watching the enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone, calming the audience, who cheers his coda. Gandhi moves to the podium with mild applause, acknowledges Patel, and prepares to speak as whispered politics continue. Jinnah listens aloofly, then returns to the platform amid tepid applause. Nehru observes Gandhi with surprise and interest, then turns to Patel. Nehru drives an open touring car with friends, dressed in British style, to a half-finished ashram, halted by a goat.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He is presiding over the Congress session, and Jinnah, with a respectful bow, takes his notes and makes a sweeping gesture toward the bustling auditorium. He is undeniably a man destined for and deeply passionate about the limelight and public attention. Eventually, he moves back to his designated spot on the platform, where Nehru warmly clasps his hand in a congratulatory manner, and others eagerly surround him to offer their approbation. Briefly, at the edge of the visual frame, we catch sight of Gandhi, the sole individual dressed in an Indian tunic, positioned at the end of the second row on the platform, simply observing the wave of enthusiasm and admiration directed at Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone, pacifying the audience with his hands raised high, and the crowd erupts into cheers and applause for his brief concluding remarks. Once again, he lifts his hands to quiet them, as Gandhi has already begun to make his way toward the podium. Gandhi is welcomed with only mild applause because the convention, having been thoroughly captivated by Jinnah's major speech, is now behaving like one entity. As Gandhi arrives at the podium, Patel signals him over, and Gandhi nods graciously in acknowledgment of the lingering applause. Patel then ambles back towards the other members, his mind already shifting toward them, though he half-hears Gandhi's comment and turns with a smile, showcasing his adaptability as a politician. Gandhi smiles broadly and retrieves glasses from his sleeve—this is the very first occasion on which we have seen them. He holds a single piece of paper with notes, placing it on the podium. He dons his glasses and faces the convention, while, on the platform, quiet murmurs of political discourse continue, and on the convention floor, some attendees listen while others engage in conversations about unrelated matters. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's final remark, turns around, prompting attention to gradually shift toward the convention floor as well. Jinnah listens from afar, with an expression both aloof and challenging, then removes his glasses, folds them carefully, and in silence, begins heading back to his place on the platform as a cameraman captures a photo, triggering scattered applause that gains lukewarm momentum here and there. On the platform, the leaders join in the applause without much enthusiasm as we glimpse an ordinary peasant face, Shukla, who we will come to recognize later, watching from the crowd of outsiders gathered in the doorways. Nehru, who has been observing Gandhi with a combination of interest and unexpected surprise, turns to speak to Patel. An open touring car lumbers along a rough, uneven trail, with Nehru himself driving, accompanied by four friends who are as young as he is, all dressed in the same costly, British-influenced attire. Nehru appears somewhat harried from the playful teasing and the jostling ride. The half-finished ashram stands with its unworked land and partially erected buildings, resembling a primitive frontier outpost. Their progress is finally halted by a goat inconveniently tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: He is currently presiding over the Congress session, and Jinnah, with a respectful and formal bow, takes his notes with him while making a grand, sweeping gesture toward the bustling and animated auditorium. He is undeniably a man destined for the limelight, and he is utterly passionate about being at the center of public attention. Eventually, he makes his way back to his designated spot on the platform, where Nehru warmly clasps his hand in a congratulatory manner, while others eagerly gather around him to offer their enthusiastic approbation. Briefly, at the very edge of the visual frame, we catch sight of Gandhi, who stands out as the only individual dressed in an Indian tunic, positioned at the distant end of the second row on the platform, quietly observing the wave of enthusiasm and admiration directed toward Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone, pacifying the lively audience with his hands raised high, prompting the crowd to erupt into cheers and applause for his brief but impactful concluding remarks. Once again, he lifts his hands to quiet them, as Gandhi has already begun to make his slow and deliberate way toward the podium. Gandhi is welcomed with only mild applause because the convention, having been thoroughly captivated and enchanted by Jinnah's major speech, is now behaving almost like a single, unified entity. As Gandhi arrives at the podium, Patel signals him over, and Gandhi nods graciously in acknowledgment of the lingering applause. Patel then ambles back towards the other members, his thoughts already shifting toward them, although he half-hears Gandhi's comment and turns with a smile, showcasing his adaptability and quick reflexes as a seasoned politician. Gandhi smiles broadly and retrieves a pair of glasses from his sleeve—this marks the very first occasion on which we have seen him use them. He holds a single piece of paper with notes, placing it carefully on the podium. He dons his glasses and faces the attentive convention, while on the platform, quiet murmurs of political discourse continue to ripple, and on the convention floor, some attendees listen intently while others engage in conversations about unrelated matters. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's final remark, turns around, prompting attention to gradually shift toward the convention floor as well. Jinnah listens from afar, with an expression that is both aloof and challenging, then removes his glasses, folds them carefully, and in silence, begins heading back to his place on the platform as a cameraman captures a photo, triggering scattered applause that gains lukewarm momentum here and there. On the platform, the leaders join in the applause without much enthusiasm as we catch a glimpse of an ordinary peasant face, Shukla, who we will come to recognize later, watching intently from the crowd of outsiders gathered in the doorways. Nehru, who has been observing Gandhi with a combination of interest and unexpected surprise, turns to speak to Patel. An open touring car slowly lumbers along a rough, uneven trail, with Nehru himself at the wheel, driving and accompanied by four friends who are as youthful as he is, all dressed in the same costly, British-influenced attire. Nehru appears somewhat harried from the playful teasing and the jostling ride. The half-finished ashram stands with its unworked land and partially erected buildings, resembling a primitive frontier outpost. Their progress is finally halted by a goat inconveniently tethered right across the path, blocking their way.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He is presiding over the Congress, exuding authority and confidence, as Jinnah respectfully bows, collects his notes with precision, and gestures grandly toward the waiting auditorium, embodying a man who thrives in and relishes the spotlight. He eventually returns to his designated spot on the platform with a sense of accomplishment, where Nehru warmly clasps his hand in a gesture of congratulations, while others eagerly gather around him, expressing their admiration. On the periphery of the scene, Gandhi is visible, notably the sole individual in an Indian tunic, seated discreetly at the end of the second row on the platform, quietly observing the wave of enthusiasm directed toward Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone with authority, commanding attention by raising his hands, which prompts the audience to cheer and applaud his brief concluding remarks. He repeats the gesture of raising his hands to quieten the audience once more, as Gandhi has begun to make his way toward the podium. Gandhi is met with polite but subdued applause, as the convention behaves as if in a routine now that the captivating effect of Jinnah's significant speech has worn off. As Gandhi reaches the podium, Patel gestures for him to proceed, and Gandhi responds with a nod of acknowledgment to the lingering applause. Patel then turns to rejoin the others, his thoughts already preoccupied with them, but he partially catches Gandhi's comment and turns back with a smile, showcasing his adaptability as a politician. Gandhi smiles back, retrieving his glasses from his sleeve—marking the first occasion we observe them—and places a single slip of paper containing his notes on the podium. He dons his glasses and turns to address the convention, while on the platform, subdued political discussions ensue and on the convention floor, some attendees listen closely as others engage in separate conversations. Nehru, having picked up on Gandhi's concluding remark, turns his attention, prompting others in the hall to begin focusing their attention as well. Jinnah listens with a detached and challenging demeanor, then removes his glasses, meticulously folding them before silently making his way back to his seat on the platform, as a cameraman captures the moment with a flash, sparking sporadic applause throughout the room. On the platform, leaders participate in the applause unenthusiastically, as we notice one particular peasant face, Shukla, whom we will become acquainted with, observing from among the crowd of outsiders positioned in the doorways. Nehru, observing Gandhi with a mixture of interest and unexpected surprise, turns toward Patel to share his thoughts. Meanwhile, an open touring car navigates a rough and uneven trail, with Nehru at the wheel, accompanied by four companions as youthful as himself, all dressed in similar costly, British-style attire. Nehru looks slightly overwhelmed by the playful teasing and the jarring ride. The ashram they approach appears half-finished, with raw, unworked land and partially constructed buildings, resembling an early frontier outpost. Their journey is eventually halted by a goat tied across the path, standing as an unexpected blockade.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: He chairs the Congress as Jinnah captivates the audience with a bow and a gesture to the auditorium, basking in the spotlight. Returning to his place, Nehru congratulates him with a handshake while others gather around. Gandhi, notably dressed in an Indian tunic, quietly observes from the second row, taking in the admiration directed at Jinnah. Patel steps up to the microphone, calming the crowd with raised hands before delivering a brief speech that draws cheers and applause. He quiets them again as Gandhi approaches the podium, greeted by mild applause now that the excitement from Jinnah's speech has waned. Gandhi acknowledges Patel's gesture to the podium with a nod. As Patel returns to the group with his mind elsewhere, he catches Gandhi's comment and responds with a smile. Gandhi, grinning, retrieves glasses from his sleeve for the first time, places a single slip of paper with notes on the podium, and faces the audience. While whispered conversations continue on the platform, more people start to pay attention on the convention floor. Nehru, after catching Gandhi's last remark, turns to focus on him, while Jinnah listens with a cool, challenging demeanor. Jinnah then removes his glasses, folds them, and silently retreats to his seat as a cameraman captures the moment, prompting scattered applause. On the platform, leaders join in tepidly, with Shukla, a peasant face we will later recognize, watching from the doorway. Nehru, intrigued and somewhat surprised by Gandhi, turns to Patel. Meanwhile, an open touring car navigates a bumpy trail with Nehru driving and four similarly attired young friends. Nehru appears slightly harassed by their teasing and the rough ride, and they stop abruptly at an unfinished ashram, resembling a primitive frontier outpost, blocked by a goat tethered across the path.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He is chairing the Congress, an annual gathering pivotal in shaping India's independence movement, and Jinnah, the prominent leader known for his sharp legal acumen and pivotal role in the formation of Pakistan, bows, takes his notes, and gestures to the auditorium—a man made for and loving the spotlight. At last, he moves back to his place on the platform, where Nehru, the future Prime Minister of independent India, clasps his hand in congratulation, and others crowd around him. Fleetingly, on the edge of the picture, we see Gandhi, the only one in an Indian tunic, signifying his commitment to traditional Indian attire for self-reliance, sitting at the end of the second row on the platform, just watching the flood of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel, a leading figure in the independence movement, approaches the microphone, stilling the house with upraised hands, and the audience cheers and applauds his little coda. He raises his hands again, stilling them, as Gandhi has already started to come toward the podium. Gandhi is greeted with mild applause because the convention is performing like one now that the spell of Jinnah's major speech has dissipated. As Gandhi reaches the podium, Patel gestures him to it, and Gandhi nods to him, acknowledging the residue of applause. Patel wanders back toward the others, his mind already on them, but he half-hears Gandhi's comment and turns with a smile, demonstrating a politician's flexibility often needed in such dynamic settings. Gandhi grins and takes glasses from his sleeve—this is the first time we have seen them, a symbol of his age and simplicity. He has one slip of paper with notes which he puts on the podium. He puts his glasses on and faces the convention, while on the platform, whispered politics continue, and on the convention floor, some listen as others talk of different things. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's last remark, turns, and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the hall too. Jinnah listens aloofly and challengingly, then takes off his glasses, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman flashes a picture, capturing a historic moment, prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. On the platform, leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one peasant face, Shukla, who we will come to know as a prominent figure in future agrarian reforms, watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru, who has been observing Gandhi with interest and some surprise at his quiet charisma, turns to Patel. An open touring car struggles along a bumpy trail with Nehru driving, accompanied by four friends as young as he, all dressed in the same expensive, British manner reflecting the colonial influence on the Indian elite. Nehru looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is half-finished, a symbol of Gandhi's vision of simple living, with unworked ground and partially completed buildings, looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path, an everyday occurrence in rural India, illustrating the blend of modernity and tradition.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. On the platform leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one peasant face Shukla who we will come to know watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru who has been observing Gandhi with interest and some surprise turns to Patel. An open touring car struggles along a bumpy trail with Nehru driving accompanied by four friends as young as he all dressed in the same expensive British manner. Nehru looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is halffinished with unworked ground and partially completed buildings looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. He puts his glasses on and faces the convention while on the platform whispered. politics continue. and on the convention floor some listen as others talk of different things. Nehru having caught Gandhi's last remark turns and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the hall too. Jinnah listens aloofly and challengingly then takes off his glasses folds them and in silence starts back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman flashes a picture prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. On the platform leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one peasant face Shukla who we will come to know watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru who has been observing Gandhi with interest and some surprise turns to Patel. An open touring car struggles along a bumpy trail with Nehru driving accompanied by four friends as young as he all dressed in the same expensive British manner. Nehru looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is halffinished with unworked ground and partially completed buildings looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: He is chairing the Congress and Jinnah bows takes his notes and gestures to the auditorium—a man made for and loving the spotlight. At last he moves back to his place on the platform where Nehru clasps his hand in congratulation and others crowd around him. Fleetingly on the edge of the picture we see Gandhi the only one in an Indian tunic sitting at the end of the second row on the platform just watching the flood of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone stilling the house with upraised hands and the audience cheers and applauds his little coda. He raises his hands again stilling them as Gandhi has already started to come toward the podium. On the platform leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one peasant face Shukla who we will come to know watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru who has been observing Gandhi with interest and some surprise turns to Patel. An open touring car struggles along a bumpy trail with Nehru driving accompanied by four friends as young as he all dressed in the same expensive British manner. Nehru looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is halffinished with unworked ground and partially completed buildings looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: He is chairing the Congress and Jinnah bows takes his notes and gestures to the auditorium—a man made for and loving the spotlight. At last he moves back to his place on the platform where Nehru clasps his hand in congratulation and others crowd around him. Nehru looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is halffinished with unworked ground and partially completed buildings looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat is chairing the Congress, and the dog bows, takes his notes, and gestures to the auditorium—a hamster made for and loving the spotlight. At last, the hamster moves back to his place on the platform, where the elephant clasps his hand in congratulation, and others crowd around the hamster. Fleetingly, on the edge of the picture, we see the rabbit, the only one in an Indian tunic, sitting at the end of the second row on the platform, just watching the flood of enthusiasm for the dog. The parrot approaches the microphone, stilling the house with upraised hands, and the audience cheers and applauds the parrot's little coda. The parrot raises his hands again, stilling them, as the rabbit has already started to come toward the podium. The rabbit is greeted with mild applause because the convention is performing like one now that the spell of the dog's major speech has dissipated. As the rabbit reaches the podium, the parrot gestures him to it, and the rabbit nods to the parrot, acknowledging the residue of applause. The parrot wanders back toward the others, his mind already on them, but he half-hears the rabbit's comment and turns with a smile, demonstrating a politician's flexibility. The rabbit grins and takes glasses from his sleeve—this is the first time we have seen them. The rabbit has one slip of paper with notes which he puts on the podium. He puts his glasses on and faces the convention, while on the platform, whispered politics continue, and on the convention floor, some listen as others talk of different things. The elephant, having caught the rabbit's last remark, turns, and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the hall too. The dog listens aloofly and challengingly, then takes off his glasses, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman flashes a picture, prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. On the platform, leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one peasant face, the turtle, who we will come to know, watching from the crowd of outsiders in the doorways. The elephant, who has been observing the rabbit with interest and some surprise, turns to the parrot. An open touring car struggles along a bumpy trail with the elephant driving, accompanied by four friends as young as the elephant, all dressed in the same expensive, British manner. The elephant looks a little harassed from the ragging and the rough ride. The ashram is half-finished, with unworked ground and partially completed buildings, looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: He is chairing the Symposium, and Jinnah bows, takes his notes, and gestures to the gallery—a man made for and loving the spotlight. At last, he moves back to his place on the balcony, where Nehru clasps his hand in congratulation, and others crowd around him. Fleetingly, on the edge of the picture, we see Gandhi, the only one in a Chinese tunic, sitting at the end of the second row on the balcony, just watching the wave of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel approaches the lectern, stilling the hall with upraised hands, and the audience cheers and applauds his little finale. He raises his hands again, stilling them, as Gandhi has already started to come toward the dais. Gandhi is greeted with mild applause because the assembly is performing like one now that the spell of Jinnah's major speech has dissipated. As Gandhi reaches the lectern, Patel gestures him to it, and Gandhi nods to him, acknowledging the residue of applause. Patel wanders back toward the others, his mind already on them, but he half-hears Gandhi's comment and turns with a smile, demonstrating a politician's flexibility. Gandhi grins and takes spectacles from his pocket—this is the first time we have seen them. He has one slip of paper with notes which he puts on the lectern. He puts his spectacles on and faces the assembly, while on the balcony, whispered politics continue, and on the assembly floor, some listen as others talk of different things. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's last remark, turns, and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the atrium too. Jinnah listens aloofly and challengingly, then takes off his spectacles, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward his place on the balcony as a photographer flashes a picture, prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. On the balcony, leaders join in perfunctorily as we see one merchant face, Shukla, who we will come to know, watching from the crowd of onlookers in the vestibules. Nehru, who has been observing Gandhi with interest and some surprise, turns to Patel. An open touring truck struggles along a rocky path with Nehru driving, accompanied by four companions as young as he, all dressed in the same elaborate, European manner. Nehru looks a little harassed from the teasing and the bumpy journey. The commune is half-finished, with untended land and partially completed structures, looking like a rudimentary frontier post. They are finally brought to a halt by a sheep tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He is observing the Congress, and Jinnah nods, scribbles his notes, and points to the auditorium—a man made for and relishing the spotlight. At last, he strolls back to his place on the platform, where Nehru pats his hand in congratulation, and others gather around him. Briefly, on the edge of the picture, we see Gandhi, the only one in an Indian tunic, lounging at the end of the second row on the platform, silently observing the swell of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel approaches the microphone, calming the house with a wave, and the audience murmurs and gestures at his little coda. He lowers his hands again, calming them, as Gandhi has already started to drift toward the podium. Gandhi is acknowledged with light applause because the convention is functioning like one now that the aura of Jinnah's major speech has waned. As Gandhi nears the podium, Patel signals him to it, and Gandhi waves to him, acknowledging the remnants of applause. Patel strolls back toward the others, his thoughts already with them, but he partly overhears Gandhi's comment and glances with a grin, revealing a politician's adaptability. Gandhi chuckles and retrieves glasses from his pocket—this is the first time we have seen them. He has one slip of paper with notes which he places on the podium. He dons his glasses and surveys the convention, while on the platform, murmured politics persist, and on the convention floor, some observe as others converse about various matters. Nehru, having perceived Gandhi's last remark, glances, and now attention begins to centralize on the floor of the hall too. Jinnah listens distantly and provocatively, then removes his glasses, collapses them, and in silence, strolls back toward his place on the platform as a cameraman clicks a picture, triggering sparse applause taken up sporadically. On the platform, leaders participate halfheartedly as we see one rustic face, Shukla, who we will come to recognize, observing from the throng of outsiders in the doorways. Nehru, who has been watching Gandhi with curiosity and some astonishment, turns to Patel. An open touring car meanders along a rocky trail with Nehru steering, accompanied by four friends as young as he, all clad in the same costly, British style. Nehru appears a bit agitated from the teasing and the jarring ride. The ashram is partially erected, with untouched ground and half-completed buildings, resembling a rudimentary frontier outpost. They are eventually brought to a pause by a goat stationed right across the path.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The mailbox is chairing the library, and the tomato bows, takes its crayons, and gestures to the skyscraper—a lamp made for and loving the spotlight. At last, it moves back to its place on the trampoline, where the pineapple clasps its hand in congratulation, and others crowd around it. Fleetingly, on the edge of the carpet, we see the cactus, the only one in a polka dot sweater, sitting at the end of the second row on the trampoline, just watching the flood of enthusiasm for the tomato. The hat approaches the microphone, stilling the pizza with upraised hands, and the jellyfish cheers and applauds its little sonnet. It raises its hands again, stilling them, as the cactus has already started to come toward the drum set. The cactus is greeted with mild applause because the zoo is performing like one now that the spell of the tomato's major speech has dissipated. As the cactus reaches the drum set, the hat gestures it to it, and the cactus nods to it, acknowledging the residue of applause. The hat wanders back toward the others, its mind already on them, but it half-hears the cactus’s comment and turns with a smile, demonstrating a sandcastle's flexibility. The cactus grins and takes marbles from its sock—this is the first time we have seen them. It has one slip of fabric with doodles which it puts on the drum set. It puts its marbles on and faces the zoo, while on the trampoline, whispered puzzles continue, and on the zoo floor, some listen as others talk of different things. The pineapple, having caught the cactus’s last remark, turns, and now attention begins to focus on the floor of the igloo too. The tomato listens aloofly and challengingly, then takes off its marbles, folds them, and in silence, starts back toward its place on the trampoline as a snowman flashes a picture, prompting tepid applause taken up here and there. On the trampoline, blankets join in perfunctorily as we see one pancake face, the trumpet, who we will come to know, watching from the crowd of guitars in the doorways. The pineapple, who has been observing the cactus with interest and some surprise, turns to the hat. An open sandwich struggles along a bumpy trail with the pineapple driving, accompanied by four beaches as young as it, all dressed in the same expensive, French manner. The pineapple looks a little harassed from the juggling and the rough ride. The hammock is half-finished, with unworked sheets and partially completed cushions, looking like a primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a teacup tethered right across the path.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The owl is narrating the carnival, and the rabbit curtsies, scribbles its notes, and points to the stage—a creature built for and thriving in the limelight. Eventually, it hops back to its perch on the stage, where the elephant pats its trunk in recognition, and others gather around it. Briefly, on the edge of the scene, we spot the fox, the only one in a woolen coat, perched at the end of the second row on the stage, merely observing the wave of admiration for the rabbit. The horse trots to the microphone, calming the crowd with raised hooves, and the spectators whistle and stomp for its brief jingle. It lifts its hooves once more, calming them, as the fox has already begun to stroll toward the podium. The fox is met with light stomping because the gathering is acting like one now that the charm of the rabbit's grand oration has faded. As the fox reaches the podium, the horse beckons it to it, and the fox winks at it, acknowledging the trace of applause. The horse meanders back toward the others, its mind already on them, but it partly hears the fox's quip and pivots with a grin, showcasing a diplomat's adaptability. The fox chuckles and extracts spectacles from its tail—this is the first time we have observed them. It clutches one slip of paper with scribbles which it places on the podium. It dons its spectacles and faces the gathering, while on the stage, hushed strategies persist, and on the convention floor, some pay heed as others chat about varied topics. The elephant, having noticed the fox's final comment, rotates, and now attention starts to concentrate on the floor of the arena too. The rabbit listens distantly and defiantly, then removes its spectacles, tucks them away, and in quiet, hops back toward its perch on the stage as a photographer captures a snapshot, inciting lukewarm applause scattered here and there. On the stage, dignitaries join in automatically as we see one canine face, Bruno, who we will soon recognize, observing from the cluster of outsiders in the entrances. The elephant, who has been noting the fox with intrigue and some amazement, turns to the horse. An ancient jalopy rattles along a rocky path with the elephant steering, accompanied by four pals as sprightly as it, all dressed in the same posh, colonial style. The elephant appears slightly flustered from the jostling and the bumpy ride. The lodge is partly constructed, with untamed terrain and partially erected structures, resembling a crude frontier outpost. They are eventually halted by a chicken roosting directly across the path.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He is sketching the Orchestra, and Jinnah curtsies, scribbles his doodles, and winks to the amphitheater—a man made for and loving the limelight. At last, he dances back to his seat on the stage, where Nehru pats his shoulder in appreciation, and others gather around him. Briefly, on the edge of the frame, we see Gandhi, the only one in an Indian robe, lounging at the end of the second row on the stage, just observing the wave of excitement for Jinnah. Patel approaches the easel, quieting the crowd with a whistle, and the spectators chant and stomp at his small encore. He claps his hands again, quieting them, as Gandhi has already started to drift toward the lectern. Gandhi is greeted with light shuffling because the assembly is functioning like one now that the aura of Jinnah's grand showcase has faded. As Gandhi reaches the lectern, Patel signals him to it, and Gandhi tips his hat to him, acknowledging the trail of claps. Patel drifts back toward the others, his mind already on them, but he half-listens to Gandhi's quip and turns with a grin, showing a politician's adaptability. Gandhi chuckles and extracts spectacles from his collar—this is the first time we have seen them. He has one petal of paper with scribbles which he places on the lectern. He slips his spectacles on and surveys the assembly, while on the stage, murmured trade-offs continue, and on the assembly floor, some eavesdrop as others chatter of various matters. Nehru, having caught Gandhi's final quip, swivels, and now attention begins to center on the floor of the arena too. Jinnah listens indifferently and defiantly, then removes his spectacles, folds them, and in silence, sails back toward his seat on the stage as a photographer snaps a shot, prompting lukewarm claps taken up sporadically. On the stage, leaders join in blandly as we see one rustic visage, Shukla, who we will come to know, gazing from the throng of onlookers in the entryways. Nehru, who has been watching Gandhi with intrigue and some astonishment, turns to Patel. An open touring boat wobbles along a rocky path with Nehru steering, accompanied by four friends as lively as he, all dressed in the same costly, British fashion. Nehru looks a little flustered from the ribbing and the rough ride. The camp is half-built, with untamed land and partially constructed huts, appearing like a primitive frontier settlement. They are finally brought to a stop by a chicken resting right across the path.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The rabbit is conducting the festival, and Marley crouches, scribbles his doodles, and waves to the gallery—a creature crafted for and savoring the limelight. Eventually, he slides back to his seat on the ledge, where Frost grips his paw in appreciation, and others gather around him. Briefly, on the margin of the sketch, we glimpse Dylan, the only one in an elephant costume, lounging at the tip of the fifth bench on the ledge, simply observing the torrent of excitement for Marley. Fitzgerald approaches the lamp, quieting the room with uplifted mittens, and the assembly chants and stomps his tiny verse. He lifts his mittens again, calming them, as Dylan has already begun to drift toward the lectern. Dylan is acknowledged with muted stomping because the assembly is behaving as one now that the charm of Marley's grand monologue has faded. As Dylan reaches the lectern, Fitzgerald signals him toward it, and Dylan shakes his head at him, recognizing the traces of stamping. Fitzgerald wanders back toward the others, his thoughts already on them, but he half-hears Dylan's quip and turns with a smirk, showcasing an artist's dexterity. Dylan grins and pulls sneakers from his hat—this is the inaugural instance we've spotted them. He has one fragment of parchment with scribbles which he lays on the lectern. He sets his sneakers on and faces the assembly, while on the ledge, murmured storytelling continues, and on the assembly floor, some gaze as others chat of varying topics. Frost, having caught Dylan's final jest, pivots, and now focus begins to settle on the floor of the chamber too. Marley observes indifferently and provocatively, then removes his sneakers, folds them, and in quiet, glides back toward his seat on the ledge as a painter snaps an image, inciting lukewarm stamping adopted here and there. On the ledge, speakers join in halfheartedly as we see one worker visage, Kim, who we will come to meet, observing from the band of spectators in the archways. Frost, who has been watching Dylan with intrigue and some astonishment, pivots to Fitzgerald. A giant pumpkin cart crawls along a jagged road with Frost steering, accompanied by four companions as aged as he, all outfitted in the same luxurious, French fashion. Frost appears slightly flustered from the teasing and the uneven journey. The hut is barely started, with untended fields and partially built structures, resembling a rustic boundary settlement. They are eventually blocked by a rabbit dozing squarely across the trail.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Jinnah chairs the Congress and, after his speech, is congratulated by Nehru and others while Gandhi, the only one in an Indian tunic, watches the enthusiasm for Jinnah. Patel quiets the audience for Gandhi, who is greeted with mild applause, as Jinnah's speech still lingers. Gandhi moves to the podium, acknowledges Patel, and prepares to speak, putting on glasses for the first time. As Gandhi speaks, some listen while others are distracted. Nehru, intrigued by Gandhi, shifts his focus, while Jinnah, aloof, returns to his seat amidst tepid applause. A peasant, Shukla, watches from the doorway. Later, Nehru drives with friends in a British-style car to an unfinished ashram, showing signs of irritation during the bumpy journey, halted by a goat on the path.
